message: I remain very interested in the concept which has been mentioned a few times here: creating a walkthrough demonstrating how to start with a story concept, find its storyform, and then develop it as far as Dramatica can take it.  The romantic comedy idea I've been playing with this week seems suitable for such a walkthrough - it's a simple plot with two main characters and a genre many people are familiar with.  So I'm going to try to synopsize the concept here as briefly as possible.  I'm not going to make any suggestions about what its storyform could be because I want to see what the group come up with.

Act 1 - A single woman decides she wants a child and is secure enough financially and socially to raise a child by herself.  She'd really rather have a loving mate who would help her raise a child, but she's failed to find that for years and she's tired of waiting.  She'll take one last shot at it - there is a town nearby which has strong local beliefs and traditions about soulmates and helping them find each other.  If this succeeds, wonderful, she'll get her baby because her soulmate will sire it.  But if (when) it fails, that town is a good vacationing place where she can go to a bar and pick up a one-night-stand to sire her baby.

Act 4 - The woman sleeps with the man, gets herself pregnant, and returns to her hometown according to plan.  However the man finds he can't stand the fact that she's gone.  The affair had distracted him from the odd experience of the matchmaking interview and the anonymous favor that was randomly done for him, but now he investigates and finds that things don't add up.  And didn't that interviewer rather resemble her lover, maybe a cousin or aunt of hers?  He discovers that his lover was staying at the hotel and tracks her back to her hometown, intending to plead with her to become more permanent lovers, even if this requires him to move to her hometown.  But when he gets there he finds out that she's pregnant and the whole story comes out.  He decides children are tolerable if they make her happy and he can keep her.  He gives her back the stone, which he has bought with him, and this is his culture's equivalent to a marriage proposal.  She accepts, yay happy ending.

Act 2 - The woman is introduced to the idea of soulmate locating magic.  Traditionally all the men in the town choose a pretty stone and perform a spell to make that stone call to the man's soulmate.  These are placed in a garden anyone can walk through.  The woman doesn't really believe in magic but finds the idea charming.  She walks through the garden admiring the stones and is surprised when one seems to call to her.  She is afraid to hope that it will really lead her to her soulmate because she can't face the pain of being disappointed again.  So instead of going through the usual channels of publicly claiming the stone and being introduced to its creator, she steals the stone and covertly looks up who created it in the public directory.  Then she disguises herself, making herself seem older and/or less attractive so that even a real soulmate would not feel strongly attracted to her if he saw her.  Then she poses as a servant of "the woman who felt drawn by the stone" and interviews the stone's creator using a matchmaking questionnaire.  The man answers all the questions the way the woman wants to hear except the most important one - when asked about children he says he doesn't like children and doesn't particularly want any.  Barely managing to hide her crushing disappointment the woman says this concludes the interview and leaves.

Act 3 - The woman is depressed but her path now seems clear - return the stone to the garden so hopefully someone else will feel drawn to it and be the man's soulmate, because he seemed really hopeful and eager at the prospect of finally meeting his fated lover.  She knows this will be difficult, maybe even painful, because the spell on the stone calls to her such that she wants to hold it close and is very reluctant to abandon it.  She feels guilty for having got the man's hopes up only to dash them by rejecting him.  This would be particularly embarrassing and pitiable in local culture if it were known that a man was rejected by his soulmate.  She hits on the idea of doing the man an anonymous favor which will make him happy, and decides this will karmically balance out her rejection of him.  Satisfied with this, she proceeds to try to carry out her plan.  The anonymous favor part works great, it does make the man very happy and she doesn't get caught.  Putting the stone back makes her cry, but she manages to do it and is somewhat proud of herself afterwards for having done the right thing.  The one night stand part, however, does not go so well.  She goes to the bar, acceptably nice and attractive men flirt with her, but she just cannot bring herself to be interested in any of them after having met someone so close to perfect.  So she finds herself back where she started the act, in her hotel room wracking her brains about what to do.  She has an epiphany - she has been so concerned about the man's potential unhappiness that she hasn't given fair consideration to her own needs.  What the man doesn't know won't hurt him - she will appear to him looking attractive, get him to sleep with her, if necessary lie about being on birth control, then once she's sure she's pregnant she'll go home with her baby, and he'll be left with a nice memory and never be put upon by being asked to help raise a child he's not interested in.
Ok, anyone is welcome to take a guess at anything here toward the goal of identifying a storyform. :)
Is this story about finding ones soul mate or about hearts desires (which would include having a baby for example)?

Well, if for finding you are thinking Obtaining and heart's desires you are thinking Innermost desires, any storyform that has Obtaining as a goal of one throughline will have Innermost Desires as the goal of another throughline.  And the other two throughline's goals will be Changing One's Nature and The Future.  The question is which goal goes with which throughline.
I wanted to generally state what this story was about. How's this, "This is a story about a goal oriented woman who has all but given up on finding her soulmate wants to have a baby."

My feeling is the Overall Story is Fixed Attitude.  Everyone has a fixed attitude about soulmates.  It seems everyone believes that there is one "soul mate" in the world for each individual.  In that line everyone is concerned with Innermost Desire.

OS Throughline of Fixed Attitude and OS Goal of Fixed Attitude seem reasonable.  Perhaps the two main disagreeing Fixed Attitudes are the focus on children vs. the focus on love.  The MC wants children even if she has to sacrifice love.  The IC wants love without the complication of children.  For a statement of what the story is about that is pretty good.  Or how about: "A creative woman who wants to have a baby finds this big current goal in conflict with her smaller long-standing goals of finding love and acting morally."  Her angsting over the ethics of her actions seems important enough to include it.

OK.  That sentence is a little convoluted (i know that sounds condescending, I don't mean to be. I am tired and my brain can't think of a better way to say it right now <g>) but I hear what you are saying.  The Relationship Story is situation.  Their relationship seems to be concerned with situations outside themselves, dependent upon the rocks and if they sing to you or if the right person walks by your rock and that person hears the rock sing to her.

Heh, my sentences are often convoluted, that's one thing I always hack on when I make a first pass at editing fiction I have written.  Sorry for any confusion.  Situation might also include the MC traveling from her home town to "romance town" and back again.  It doesn't seem very intuitive to me that these situation things correspond to the relationship throughline, but I'll go along with it.  Situation might even stretch to include the fact that when the MC doesn't look like herself the man doesn't recognize or react to her as a soulmate.  Though the part about her choosing to wear a disguise would be in Manipulation.

True.  These are just first responses.  I guess you could see wearing the disguise as an activity to learn or understand.  Wearing the disguise could be just a methodology to learn what she needs to make her decision.  Do you want to make an argument for something that feels more intuitive?

Well, my initial idea of what the throughlines are was the same as what you came up with: OS Situation, MC/IC Fixed Attitude, MC Activity, IC Manipulation.  But that resulted in a plot progression where all the signposts seemed to be in the wrong throughline.  So for my second attempt I used: OS Activity, MC/IC Manipulation, MC Situation, IC Fixed Attitude.  I'm not sure which version I prefer.  But I'll list my reasons for the second version so you can compare and say whether you agree or disagree.

OS Activity - Everyone is either making soulmate stones or looking through the collection to find one that calls to them.  Both characters investigate the other's identity, travel to the other's location, and make an attempt to obtain something from the other.  MC/IC Manipulation: The MC wears the costume specifically to manipulate how the IC reacts to her.  The contemplation in the story is primarily the MC evaluating her actions toward the IC and evaluating how she would feel in different possible versions of a relationship with the IC or lack of a relationship with him; also the IC reevaluates his desire to avoid children the the context of his relationship with the MC.  Any memories involved are mainly of the lonely lack of a relationship and hopeful seeking of a relationship.  MC Situation, well, I often have trouble seeing the relevance of past/present/change/future to anything in my stories; but the MC does seem to be worrying about possible change in a way no one else is, and she's at least as focused on the future as anyone else.  IC Fixed Attitude, he doesn't want kids and he embodies local culture wrt the magic stones and soulmates by believing firmly that a woman who felt the call of his stone is his soulmate and he should definitely be with her, it's unthinkable to just let her just leave.
there is the morality/self interest.

Could the theme include how finding ones soul mate is not enough.  There is still work to be done.  I couple, no matter how ideal, must work together to find a shared vision of a life together.  Even ideal matches have different goals and to have a good and healthy relationship they must have a shared vision of a life together, not my goals and not your goals, but our goals.  Because I love you I want you to be happy and because you love me you want me to be happy.  It is not compromise. it is a third alternative that is better than either of the single hearts desires alone.  The sum is greater than it's parts.

The challenge with more than one person working on this is that when creating a story we could choose any story form and tell this romantic story. (imho) it would be skewed.  So, will you take the lead and make final decisions?  The "learning the lesson of creating a shared vision of a life together" would be my story focus.  I like the idea that even soul mates have to work at having a successful relationship.

Although it's a pleasant theme I don't think that the theme of work to make a relationship successful fits with the plot as-is because the MC and IC aren't together as a couple until the end of the story.  I've seen romances with that theme and they have to start farther along the progression of the relationship, the characters need to already get together or be together at the beginning.  So that could work as a sequel of this, but is not a good fit for this plot as laid out above.  I could see the "finding one's soulmate is not enough" part though, since the woman chooses having a child over having her soulmate.

As far as who makes choices for the storyform, I think it would be valuable to any readers of a walkthrough to see us consider different possibilities and explain why each might be chosen.  I'd really like to discuss in more detail in what ways each of the two possibilities for throughline assignment would skew the story's development.  It is probably a common problem for new and intermediate Dramatica users to accidentally choose a storyform that skews their story in a way different than they intended, and as a result feels awkward or unnatural.  I've had that problem multiple times.

Let's look at Activity first, I often find that one of the easiest types of content to identify in any story because it's easy to identify actions within a plot outline.  Not all the actions in the story will be part of Activity, but if we make a list of all the actions in the plot, the lion's share of them should be in whichever throughline is Activity, right?  So what have we got.  The IC and others in his town make soulmate stones.  The MC travels to romance town, to the soulmate stone garden within romance town, to the IC's house, to a bar, and back to her hometown.  The IC travels to the MC's hotel and home town.  The MC and IC each briefly investigate each other.  The MC in disguise interviews the IC, then later seduces him and uses him to get herself pregnant.  So which throughline is the majority of that in?  I think we can safely rule out IC because the MC is doing at least twice as many actions as the MC and he only takes action in response to outside pressures, specifically his culture's instructions and the MC's vanishing act.  Now the question is whether the IC is taking actions to a significant degree or not.  If not, Activity would have to be the MC throughline.  If yes, then the question is whether these actions are being taken by everyone, or whether they are being done specifically by the two characters to each other.

So Overall Story in Activity.  You made a pretty good argument for this as well as the Relationship Story in Manipulation.  The Main Character's Story is in Situation.  Her Situation which is unbalanced is she does not have a soul mate and she does not have a child.  She is focused on changing this situation.  The Impact Character Story is Fixed Attitude.  He believes in this soulmate stone magic.  He also has a fixed attitude of not wanting children which causes conflict in the story.
That sounds good to me.  Let's move forward with this as the identifications of the throughlines then.  What shall we do next, character dynamics, plot dynamics, throughline issues...?
Do you think it's obviously a type 1D here or could a case be made for type 1B or one of the others?  http://www.dramatica.com/downloads/BigFour2Large.png
I am not sure but I like 1C and 1D and I am leaning toward 1C.  I am more comfortable start with the main character.  Is she change or steadfast?

I'm not sure whether she's change or steadfast.  If I had to guess, steadfast.  She does have a fairly big moment of epiphany at the end of act three where she changes approach to getting what she wants, but she keeps the same goal the whole way through.  The IC changes his Fixed Attitude which is more central to him.  (And that's a general rule, one of the MC and IC must be steadfast and the other change, so when I decide that I always look at the two characters and ask myself which changes more profoundly.)  I do think that the MC is an intuitive do-er (do-er is required by her througline being Situation anyway), while the IC is a logical be-er.  Do you agree, or have any arguments to the contrary?

Her growth is stop.  What is the situation she is waiting for to stop?  If it were start I would say she wants her life with a family to start.  In this case I will say she is waiting for the loneliness to stop.  No, that is a be-er statement.  She is waiting to stop being alone.
yes, I agree, She is definitely a do-er and now that you say it she IS an intuitive do-er.  She looks at the whole and comes to conclusions.  I don't see her as a linear thinker.
I would have guessed she was start and the IC was stop, but you're right this configuration of throughlines requires the MC to be stop.  I wonder why.

I also agree that she is a steadfast character. It adds a different dynamic that everyone is concerned with obtaining a soul-mate but she has all but given up on a soul-mate and her main goal is to have a child.  She's not the antagonist but it's almost like she is the contagonist in the overall story.

Glad you agree. :)  That's why I switched in the adjective creative for her instead of goal-oriented when we were talking about the theme.  She IS goal oriented, but many or most goal oriented people are more logical or linear thinkers, so I thought that might be misleading.  I think the fact that she does the man an unrelated favor to "balance her karma" after abstractly harming him by not telling him she's his soulmate is the clearest example of her intuitive or holistic thought.  From this outline it's not as clear but I think the way the MC is thinking about the future as a situation where several factors may or may not be present and together they add up to whether each possible future would make her happy or not.  The IC on the other hand, his thoughts are quite linear goal-solution pairs: Everyone knows soulmates are good, therefore he'll make a soulstone like everyone else.  He finds children annoying in general, therefore he won't have any.  He wants to keep his soulmate, if she demands children to be with him then ok, compromise on that.

That's interesting, seeing her as the contagonist of the overall story; the OS has kind of a fate/destiny push going on with the soulmate cultural beliefs and magic, while the MC is avoiding this by not reporting that the stone called her, wearing a disguise which prevents her soulmate from recognizing her as such, and being willing to just leave him and go home even after they have become lovers, which is unthinkable from the point of view of everyone else.  It fits with my image of her as being almost an anti-villain.  Have you seen the movie Megamind, or Dr. Horrible's sing-along blog?  The main characters of those stories are official supervillains, which the woman here clearly isn't, but they are in the same position of having a different, non black-and-white understanding of what is "good" than everyone else.  They take the sneaky approach because it works, and if that makes people who see all untruth as Evil with a capital E see them as villains, oh well.  They have their own personal moral code and are true to it.  Megamind and Dr. Horrible are both change characters (I assume) which is shown by the fact that they both end up subsumed into "everyone else"s idea of right and wrong at the end: one become a hero, the other becomes a true villain instead of an anti-villain.  The MC of this story does neither; she sticks to her beliefs and the IC bends instead.

it's the relationship of the MC situation to the OS activity.  the horizontal relationship.  That doesn't really say why but that is how the program works.  I would think it would be more if a character moves from a state to a process or visa verso.

She stops putting others before herself, stops ignoring her own desires, stops being overly cautious about ethics, or something along those lines?  More practically, she stops hiding herself from her soulmate/avoiding sex with him.

I could see an equal argument for approach/attitude though.  Problem is that she is changing her attitude about the morality of self interest and as a result of her changed attitude, changes her approach.  It's all in there somewhere.

Do you have a feeling about the story driver or limit.  I would say it is definitely an option lock.   Lately I like to leave the driver blank because it gives me more options and make the story fit the driver but do you have a strong feeling about it.?

As far as Outcome I was going to say Success but now I might leave it blank.  It seems there could be varying degrees of success and failure.  Does everyone obtain a soul-mate?  The Judgement is good. Our main Character gets her child and the soul-mate.

On the other hand she succeeds at obtaining her child, succeeds at getting the IC to sire the child (is that another kind of obtaining?) and the IC temporarily succeeds at obtaining his soulmate as his lover, which is the main thing he wanted, even though he doesn't realize it's her.

Note for record-keeping:  At the current point there are 16 storyforms remaining.  The choices which have been made so far are: Resolve - Steadfast.  Growth - Stop (implied by other choices).  Approach - Doer.  PS Style - Intuitive.  Driver: Decision.  Limit: Optionlock.  Outcome: Success.  Judgment - Good.  OS Throughline - Activity (implies MC/IC Throughline - Manipulation).  MC Throughline - Situation (implies IC Throughline - Fixed Attitude).  OS Concern - Obtaining (Implies MC/IC Concern - Changing One's Nature, MC Concern - Future, and IC Concern - Innermost Desires).  At this point the OS and IC Plot Progressions (aka signposts) have already been determined.  Two options remain for each of the other two plot progressions.  4 Issue choices, 2 Unique Ability/Catalyst Choices, 2 Critical Flaw/Inhibitor Choices, and 16 possibilities for each of Problem, Solution, Symptom, and Response remain for each throughline.  If we wanted to the number 16 is small enough that we could theoretically make all 16 storyforms and compare the reports for them to see which we like best.  That would be a lot of work though, lol.

Okay, here's a third opinion on some of this stuff.
Limit: Optionlock. Not only is there no time limit in play, the protagonist (the woman) has only so many things to try before this plan is played out.
Driver: She decides she wants a child (start), he decides having a child is okay (end). She decides to put on make-up and a disguise in the middle, etc.

Beyond that, I don't think much has been sorted out. 
Why hasn't the woman met her soulmate? Is it because she's run away from him in the past -- implying an internal issue? Is it because of a shortage of good men -- implying an external issue? 
If anything, the only real problem that's been put out there is that she wants a child, and that is an obstacle to the man. Is that because he's afraid he's going to be a bad father, like his own father was -- implying an internal issue? Or is it because children lead to financial ruin and divorce -- implying an external issue?

You seem to be concentrating on the setting of the story (finding a mate in a magical town) but not on the things that cause hiccoughs. You need both, and specifically you need to find the source of the problems.
No she goes to the town to get pregnant

@sunandshadow You're jumping all over the place with your approach, specifically considering problem/solution pairs, and I think it's too early to do that, especially if you are trying to use this to create a template that can be used to build stories using Dramatica. I'm going to try to pull the reins really hard, so the approach proceeds slowly.
I'm going to skip Do-er, Intuitive, Steadfast for now. You can declare them to be true -- that's the author's right. But I think we should skip them until other parts of the story are sorted out.

To be clear, what I've said doesn't make the town an OS thing, and her issue internal.

She could have a huge nose (Cyrano de Bergerac) and that causes her problems.

The town could be on top of a methane pit (not romantic, but people get woozy, feel spellbound and fall in love) -- that's external. OR, the mayor of the town could be so adamant that people fall in love that he sabotages people's vehicles until they fall in love -- making it a Fixed Attitude.

First Thing: Soulmate as external problem.

You are building this on assumptions. First, that everyone has a soulmate. Second, that enough of these soulmates are men from this particular town -- especially for women coming from out of town -- that the town has a ritual and a reputation. Third, that this particular woman satisfies #1 and #2.

I just want to point out that you have the woman find the stone and then NOT want to meet the guy, implying that there is something internal going on with her that is keeping her away from Romance. That might make not finding her soulmate an internal problem.

The thing to make sure is uber clear then is what issues belong to the OS and which belong to her. Here is one way to deal with all of this. (It's not the only way.)

A different approach would be that this town has a reputation for Romance. Men and Women come to the town, and partake in the ritual (men sing to the stones and cast them in the garden in the morning. Women walk through at noon and see if any of the stones speak to them...). This deals with #1 and #2 in a different way: that we don't all have unique soulmates -- we just have to be open to romance, and there is a constant flow of men and women from all over to repopulate the mating pool. 

Then, give the woman a problem that keeps her from "pulling the trigger.
So... you're in charge. What do you want to do from here?

Okay, let me comment on these assumptions about the woman and the town.  1st, it is a fantasy world where it is a truth of the world that everyone has at least one soulmate.  It might be possible that around the world any given person might have 30 people of the right gender, appearance, and personality to qualify as a soulmate.  Once they spend some time with one they bond with that one and their own soul stops looking around for others.  In general this isn't relevant to the story since it's only about this one woman and the first man she's ever recognized as someone who resonates with her soul.  2nd, both men and women of this town make soulstones.  Again, this is not relevant because the stones made by women are on the other side of the garden, the MC never goes there, and the IC has been there but never found a woman's stone that resonated with him.  The difference between this town and the MC's hometown is that this town thinks soulmates are the best thing ever and they have devoted a lot of time and attention to developing soulmate-seeking magic and traditions.  The MC's hometown is skeptical that soulmates exist or are important so they have focused their own development of magic on more tangible things, such as crafting physical objects and earning money in business.

When the woman finds the stone she does immediately want to look at the guy; what she wants is a one-sided meeting, her meeting him but him not meeting her.  Thus the disguise preventing him from recognizing her as a soulmate because appearance is about 30% of what makes people potential soulmates.  What she is afraid of is committing herself to a bad future because this guy is a total unknown (he might have a violent temper or something), she doesn't have the faith that soulmates are the best thing since sliced bread that everyone in this town including the IC does, her first priority is protecting herself and her future child.  Thus the questionnaire, because she wants to know everything about this guy before she commits to meeting him as a potential soulmate.

About the idea of jumping around with approach, I actually think one of the best things about Dramatica is there are half a dozen different places to start and you can do them in whichever order seems easiest.  So I was imagining the walkthrough would try to tackle each of these potential starting points without relying on what had been decided already, if possible.  Instead of "Do step one, build on step one to do step two, build on step two to do step three..." I would like to create a document that says, "Here are steps 1-6, look at them all and choose the one that seems easiest to do first."
Sorry, my thing posted before I wanted it to, and I had only seen one of your three posts. Weird.

"it is a fantasy world where it is a truth of the world that everyone has at least one soulmate."
I thought you were saying that everyone has *one* soulmate, which is very different.

Also, now you're saying that her town has "focused their own development of magic on more tangible things" yet this woman does not believe in magic (from the early messages).

So, which is it? Because the main thing that I am trying to point out is that the story does not seem very clear. The edges are not defined.

She must believe in soulmates enough to go to the town. I understand being skeptical. But when the town's rocks point one out to her, her assumption is that a future with him might be bad!

This is not belief in a soulmate!

But that is okay. It just means that her problem, or the OS problem, lies in that gap.

Does she think there is a different kind of hoodoo going on? Does she get uncomfortable with this kind of soulmate seeking? What is that gap? 

That is the inequity you have to sort out.

Or...

She has to believe in soulmates and immediately go to the guy... only to find out that there was no lightning bolt of love when they met. That is a different inequity that has to be solved.

The story is in there.

She wants a baby, but she'd rather have a soulmate. Which is great because if she meets her soulmate, then he can sire the baby. But she goes to the town to get pregnant, even though she is going to the town to give it one last chance to find her soulmate.

What?
This introduces nice problems, too. Because she could have her eye on one guy -- but the town pushes someone else on her.

Also, in terms of creating a walk-through, verses jumping around... I think that's fine. But I think it needs to be contained somewhat. Jumping straight to the problem can be okay if you really have a sense of what you want to do. But saying "it could be this, it could be that" to me sends  up strong signals not to go there.

I think you need to figure out if she wants a baby, wants a soulmate, or thinks she wants a baby, but it's really a justification not to find a soulmate, or wants a soulmate, but uses the baby as a way to not commit... Saying she wants a baby, but she's going to give finding a soulmate one last go, and then opting to just try to get pregnant... I can see it. But then she has a problem of being indecisive and manipulative and self-serving.

I don't know how to say it another way. I think you are trying to have your cake and eat it, too.

I just don't understand how going to interview the guy while in make-up is the rational action considering that all she wants is a baby.

I get the dilemma you're setting up, and have no issue with it. It's the way you're getting there that I have issue with.
And, are the twelve questions not a walk-through?

I know it's a fuzzy concept, and I just want to make sure that the approach to cleaning it up acknowledges that. Once you make a decision, other things can no longer be chosen.

And, I think it all starts at the top. If she wants a baby, why does she even go into the garden to find a soulmate... unless it's to con him into sleeping with her so she can get pregnant and vamoose? Why is she even concerned about a future with the guy or about love? She should be using it to manipulate the guy into the bedroom.

She can only be there to try to solve one problem. 
If a second one arises as an unexpected consequence to solving the first one, that's fine. But her active pursuit of it is a story-telling no-no as far as I'm concerned.

Well, this isn't an existing story we are analyzing, this is a vague concept we are developing toward a fleshed-out story.  So, I think it's natural that there are fuzzy edges.  I apologize for being inconsistent about the woman belief in magic though.  But I do think that her want to have a baby is a totally different kind of goal than wanting to have a soulmate, or as she thinks of it since she's not totally invested in the concept of soulmates, a lover.  The desire to get pregnant is an immediate, strong, specific desire that spurs her to the specific action of going to the other town.  The other town has a reputation as a great place for a sexy vacation - her main plan is to do exactly that, take a vacation, find a guy good enough to have sex with, and go home with the baby she wanted.  The desire to have love on the other hand is something that's been part of the background of her life for years.  It's something she feels wistful about, not a problem she actively wants to attack.

What she is looking for is a guy to be a babydaddy.  But she thinks a guy who wanted to be her lover and father to her children would be a superior babydaddy than some random guy she's never going to see again.  To create the biggest possible conflict for her, she finds a guy who she almost immediately starts to fall for, he would very likely fall in love with her, BUT he doesn't want kids.  I wanted it to be a situation where she wants to eat her cake (get pregnant) but is then presented with the contradictory possibility of having her cake (acquiring a lover) and what she really wants to do is have both so she carefully and slowly tries to finagle the situation to get as close to having both as she can. The OS is an objective look at the world. The MC is a subjective look at the world. 

This means that if you have someone on a rock-climbing expedition, you get a breakdown like this:
Protagonist: Get to the top of the rock wall.
MC: overcome my fear of heights.

The same person -- the same physical body -- is climbing the wall. But the "novice rock climber" is the Protagonist, and the "person afraid of heights" is the MC.

The things that the novice rock climber encounters and has to deal with (making sure she has all of her equipment) are not the same thing the agoraphobe has to deal with (forcing herself to trust the carabiners will support her weight). 

It's tricky, because in a single sentence you can writer, "Mandy was terrified at the way the rope pulled through the carabiner, but was determined to reach the top," and be referring to both storylines! 

But, this person could get 90% up the wall and feel as though she's conquered her fear of heights (judgement: good) but the Protagonist will still have Failed.

When you refer to someone in the OS by their subjective role, you confuse which issue the character is dealing with.
